data.message: 21.  Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
Nah probably not. I only started smoking to help deal with panic attacks.
Yeah I probably would have started a few years earlier.
I was really young when I started smoking so I doubt i could've started even younger than I already was.
Maybe so. I started smoking flavored cigarettes very young. Not because of the flavor, just because it was all that was available to us.
Absolutely
Possibly. I didn't really start smoking daily until I was 19 but I had tried it at 13. If I had access to flavored cigarettes at that age, I may have started sooner.
Not really, up until about two years ago, I never even picked up a cigarette before. I was scared of what might happen if I actually lit one. Flavored cigarettes wouldn't have any difference

20.  Part of the new Tobacco Legislation is that physicians and clinicians must encourage and help their smoking patients quit. Do you think help from a health professional would motivate you to quit? #smokingaffectsall
I think so, yes. Anything can help it just depends on how bad you want it.

Not necessarily, it depends on the success and expertise of the health professional, and whether he or she can comprehend their clients. Comprehension is the key to overcoming addiction, most don't see that. You must know what you're doing in order for you to stop doing it. Health professionals can help quit smoking if and only if he or she steps our of their generalizations.

I had a back injury last year and had an MRI done. My doctor said that my spine is like a 35-year-old's spine (I'm 25) and said that smoking is probably the main reason for that. It definitely put it in my head that smoking is not helping me any and is aging me faster and probably cutting a chunk of life off me, so I would say yes. The more I think about it, the more I realize I should quit to save my life. And hearing it from a doc definitely puts it into perspective.
Not really, no. Everyone knows that smoking is harmful.
Maybe  if they did more than pass out pamphlets.
It didn't motivate me anymore and my PCP has been encouraging me for years.
Not really. I have heard about the harmful effects of smoking most of my life, so having a doctor  talk about it doesn't make much of a difference.
19.  Who’s that one friend you can count on to listen to you when you need it? Who will you be able to trust as your supporter when you are ready to quit smoking? #support
My girlfriend, and my best friend are always there for me.
My best friend at work.
My boy toy!
My boyfriend, my brother, the doctor I work with.
My best friend at work.
My best friend. And most of my family are always there for me.
My boyfriend.

Hi everyone!First of all, thanks to everyone who has been commenting on the posts. We really appreciate your input, no matter what it is. Thank you for being so active!On the note of incentives, I want to make sure everything is clear. This group has weekly incentives, which means that you have to comment every single day of that week in order to get $7 for that week. You can either get $0 or $7 per week, there are NO in betweens!If the Tsp Study page has liked a post already, that means I have already checked that post for your comments and you can no longer comment on it to count for incentives!Some of you have gotten 6 out of 7 days of a week and are NOT going to be paid for that week because you didn't get all 7. I just wanted to be clear on that so no one is confused! The weeks go by every 7 posts: post #1 - #7 are week 1, posts #8 - #14 are week 2, etc.Thanks Victoria from TSP

18.  Now that you’ve made your list of cons for quitting smoking, let’s consider your top reason not to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting here and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: "I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________." #beingconscious
I'm worried that I don't have the strength to quit for good.
I'm worried that it's affecting my fertility and will destroy it.
I'm worried about my health later on in life and how it's affected.
I'm worried that it will only be temporary.
I'm worried that I will just end up going back to it like I always do.
I'm worried that I will keep going through the same cycle of trying to quit, being unsuccessful every time.
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII
I just chose cutting back. smoking half a cigarette instead of a full one so that I reduced consumption. It went alright. But still a bad habit
Hi 10408 - and would you recommend it to someone who is trying to quit? What in your experience is crucial to making it work?
Yes cutting back is a good strategy. But you still have the same cravings. I think nicotine replacement would be better for me. Instead of still smoking cigarettes
Yeah 10408 - nicotine replacement can be quite effective to reduce those cravings. Have you given any more thought to which strategy or product you would like to use in a future quit attempt?
I have. I think the gum would work best for me. any particular brand that you recommend? Johannes Thrul

No not really - you can just choose one in your local pharmacy. Just make sure to follow these instructions when you use it - many people chew it like a normal gum and don't like the results: Chew nicotine gum slowly until you can taste the nicotine or feel a slight tingling in your mouth. Then stop chewing and place (park) the chewing gum between your cheek and gum. When the tingling is almost gone (about 1 minute), start chewing again; repeat this procedure for about 30 minutes. How many cigarettes do you smoke on an average day?
Johannes Thrul I'd say 10-15

So you could either start with the 4mg or the 2mg gum. Do you usually smoke within the first 30 mins after waking? That may be an indicator for using the stronger one. Also, which state do you live in? There may be options to get free nicotine replacement from the smokers quitline.
10408 - you can google "your state" and "smokers quitline" to find out more. I've got to run but I'll see you next week!
Thanks Doc! Johannes Thrul
17.  All change has pros and cons. What are some of the cons of quitting smoking? Why might it be hard for you to quit? #beingconscious
The peer pressure of all my smoker friends,  and being around them.
The habit. Humans are creatures of habit.
I get extremely irritable without nicotine, so it would be hard for me to quit smoking while working with the public.

We are all human and we all have different ways to cope with the daily stresses of life. Once a habit is once that alleviates these stresses, it's like taking a dance with the devil. Once a person quits smoking, its going to be a daily taunt for a whole, our conscience is going to let it be clear that there are others in the world that can still smoke and lead a fulfilling life. We are going to want to pick up a cigarette again, that's just the bottom line.
Dealing with a panic attack without a cigarette. I've been dealing with panic attacks this way for years now.

I just like smoking. It gives me a reason to take a break at work instead of working through. It feels good and I just feel better when I smoke. It'll be hard to quit because I've been doing it for so long and I don't think theres anything else out there that can replace smoking for me.
Having to give up what I've used as a method of stress reduction for years.

16.  Quitting can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is released into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke? #beingconscious
Less waste on the side of the road.
Definitely less butts on the ground.
Less ash, tobacco, cigarette butts, less waste of paper to make packs and cartons.
Maybe less carbon monoxide in the air. I know smoke isn't good for the ozone
Less carbon monoxide in the air, along with other chemicals, and there would also be less litter on the roads
No butts everywhere, less chemicals, healthier people
The world will be less littered by the remnants of addiction. Cigarette butts

15.  What strategy do you plan to use when you do decide to quit smoking? Will you use any Nicotine Replacement Therapies (like patch or gum)? Medication? Cold turkey? Counseling? Share your plan of action and see if any other group members are on the same page! #beingconscious
Medication and willpower. I've never been required to quit, and now that is the case. I have something else to focus on until the urge passes.

I'd like to attempt to gradually decrease,  one cig on my way to work instead of two (same for the drive home), skip the afternoon smoke break, and  limit myself to two in the evening,  and gradually taper down from there.
I've already decreased the amount I smoke. I just go cold turkey when I finally decide to stop.
Probably cold turkey.
I think the best way for me would be cold turkey.
I want to do cold turkey. But I think a nicotine replacement would work better for me .
I think I'm going to cold turkey my addiction because it would take the most willpower and probably lead me to stop smoking for good.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 10.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: 14.  On a scale of 1-10 (with 10 being most important), how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #beingconscious
6ish. It helps me deal with stress and mental health issues. Not the best way to deal with it, but not the worst either.
7. I want to but need motivation
7. I know I need to quit for upcoming surgery. And overall, I know it would be better for my health to quit permanently.
6. I know I need to quit for my health but I don't have much motivation to do so.
Probably 5. It'd be cool to quit to save some money and be healthier but I actually like smoking lol.
5. I only want to quit for other people,  not for myself.
13.  Do you know anyone who has died from a tobacco-related disease? How did their death affect your own smoking? Post and share your experiences. #reflection
My best friends step dad is currently dying because of smoking related cancer. He had to get that hole in his throat. I had already slowed up my smoking by then, so it hasn't really affected it.
My grandmother died from lung cancer. It was when I was very young before I ever started smoking so it didn't really have any effect on my smoking habits.
My grandmother also passed away from lung cancer when I was young. I didn't start smoking till 15 year later.
My grandmother died of emphysema when I was 5,  and because I was so young I did not put her sickness and smoking together.
I haven't known anyone close to me that has had any so i haven't been affected, yet. No one smokes in my family so I guess I don't have motivation to quit in that department

My grandfather died from lung cancer, which is a total oxymoron, given the fact that I struggle with smoking myself. It kind of scares me actually to think that addiction runs in my family. I don't want to be the end of the cycle, or even part of the cycle and let my addiction get the best of me.

12. Did you know that the number of non-smokers affected by second hand smoke is more than double the number of actual smokers in the U.S.? Who is affected by your second hand smoke? #smokingaffectsall
I try to be respectful and not smoke around people, but indirectly my children and coworkers are affected simply by my clothes at the very least.
I knew this. I try to be respectful but wind exists.
I didn't know this. But i also try to be respectful. I usually only smoke around "smokers"
I usually smoke alone in my car,  or alone out on the porch, but if we go out,  people on the street,  I guess.
I have a couple people at work who don't smoke cigarettes so whenever I smoke a cigarette, they get really disgruntled. They hate the smell of it and hate when I smoke around them basically.
I'd say my boyfriend is the most affected by my second hand smoke, and a few of my non-smoking friends who don't mind if I smoke around them.
I try to avoid smoking around non-smokers, but I also know it can't always be helped in certain places (ie bars that allow smoking).

11.  Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or Nicotine Replacement Therapies (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. What are your thoughts on e-cigs? Have/would you ever try one? #ecig
I tried it but it just wasn't satsifing.
I absolutely love ecigs and I live by them on a daily basis since I've stopped smoking cigarettes. I don't know, I think it's something about the vapor itself or something.
I've tried it but they hurt my cheeks and I'm not a fan of them. They're also heavier than a real cigarette and just not as good to me.
I've tried them, but I don't care for them. I've tried a good handful of different ones, but they're not the same as a cigarette and they hurt my throat.
Tried them,  but I missed the burn and hated the medical hint they left in my throat
I've tried them. They aren't good at all for me. I'm ready to try nicotine replacement such as gum.
I've tried them, but they just make me want to smoke more than I originally did. I prefer using the nicotine gum.
What is currently your biggest smoking trigger? #TDII
Boredom.
Hi 10450, boredom is definitely a big trigger for many folks. What kind of situations are these typically?
Specifically when I'm working. Boredom (and with it, the urge to smoke) strikes when I'm sitting at my desk doing paperwork or scanning charts.
10450, have you ever experimented with alternatives other than smoking that help you deal with boredom? If so how did it go?
Stress. When shit hits the fan, I want a cigarette the most.
Friends and social gatherings, especially with alcohol involved

Hi 10327 & 10408 - stress and social situations with other smokers around can be major triggers as well. I'm curious - have you ever experimented with alternatives other than smoking to deal with the cravings?
Chewing gum but that gets boring and doesn't give me the "calming" effects that I thought nicotine did for me.
That's understandable 10327 - you may want to try the nicotine gum sometime, which has the added advantage that it would provide this additional effect.
Hi Doc, I tried e-cigs for about a week and didn't enjoy the harshness on my throat. I've wanted to try the patch or gum but haven't done it yet.
I've tried doing pushups (or exercise in general), which can help, but is not always feasible at work...

Hi 10408 - I would definitely recommend nicotine replacement as these medications can really increase your chances of quitting successfully and help deal with cravings. If you want to find out about your options check out these resources: http://smokefree.gov/explore-medications

The nicotine gum still doesn't give me the full effect of smoking a cigarette. Maybe it is the oral fixation with the cigarettes themselves and seeing the fact that I can make smoke, if that makes any sense at all. I have an e-cigarette and that helps , but the craving a for a real cigarette is still there.
Sorry guys, I have to run. Great discussion today - see you next week!
Thanks a bunch! Great article Johannes Thrul

10.  Remember Drawback #1 ("I don't want to have withdrawal symptoms") from yesterday’s post? Which one of our following comebacks works for you? #balance • Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing• I may be coughing more because the cilia (hair-like structures that line my lungs and clean the air I breathe) that were paralyzed by the cigarette smoke are starting to work again, which makes me temporarily cough more• I may have tingling in my arms and legs because my circulation is improving
The first one. Coughing is terrible and nothing will ever make coughing okay.
Coughing! I didn't know I could cough more if I stopped smoking.  That's a relief for me to hear
The first one. Coughing isn't fun
The first one would help me the most.
The first one.
The first one for sure.
Coughing definitely.

9.  Research shows that emphasizing the benefits of quitting over the drawbacks helps smokers quit their habit for good. Try your hand at making a negative a positive. What’s your comeback for this drawback? #balance
Once you get past the first week or two of withdraw symptoms than you have your whole life of healthier lungs
It doesn't last forever. District yourself.
Withdrawal is worth a lifetime of being healthy.
The withdrawal is worth it in the long run.
You get over withdrawal after a few days or weeks at the most, and then you're healthier, have more money, and whiter teeth lol.
Soon they will go from being withdrawals to being health benefits that will make you feel better than smoking ever did.
I never really had withdrawal symptoms, only like really bad cravings, I do feel if you actually sit down and look at the negative aspects of quitting smoking, it'll make it more worthy

8.  Here are some things to help you maintain your awesome physique when you stop smoking. Which one seems the most helpful? #balance • Make sure you have a well-balanced diet• Chew sugarless gum when you want something sweet• Eat slowly• Plan healthy, low-fat and low-calorie snacks into your day• Watch portion sizes• Read food labels
Probably low calorie snacks
Make sure you have a well balanced diet
Balanced diet thing
Portion control would help me most.
Portion control,
Probably a well balanced diet and portion control!
Chewing sugarless gum.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 10.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you!

data.message: 7.  Weight gain is one of the top concerns for almost every smoker. We’ve made a list of some tips that can help keep your weight on track while you quit. Pick the one sounds good to you. How could you implement it into your life? #balance • Go for a walk, swim, bike ride or any exercise you enjoy• Find small ways to be more active, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or parking a little farther away• Find alternatives to snacking, like calling a friend• Drink some extra water
Great advice

As a major coke drinker,  I feel like cutting out my soda intake would easily negate the effects of quitting.  But then I wouldn't have my nicotine,  or my caffine. I'm sure I'd be a horror to interact with.

I'm already outside walking all day for work. Several miles 6 days a week. So exercise isn't really a concern, and weight gain from quitting wouldn't be a concern for me either because I have plenty to keep me busy. Smoking is actually a good excuse for me to take a break because I'm constantly go go go. And I don't drink anything but water and coffee, around 80oz of water a day.
Finding ways to enjoy exercising and finding healthier snacks would be the best way for me to fight weight gain.
I'm not too concerned about gaining weight after quitting. I just moved and starting walking to and from work which has been helping with losing weight.
I just joined the gym

Because I am a waitress, I am constantly on my feet. I feel as though exercise is not a priority for me, given my health condition and the fact that I have never had trouble losing weight, it happens quite easily. While trying to quit smoking, my appetite has actually heightened. In this scenario, I think I should find more outdoor activities to indulge in, such as a weekly hike or something of that nature.
6.  What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #balance

If I quit smoking, I would probably be in better health in the long run. Also, I would save a lot of money on what I would spend on cigarettes if I was still smoking. I would be able to breathe easier.
I wouldn't smell like cigarettes and be less likely to get cancer.
Not having my health care providers and doctors at work harassing me about my health, being healthier, and saving money are all pretty good benefits to quitting.
Saving money. Definitely saving money.

Stop hiding it from my family.  My grandmother died from lung cancer, and it was slow and painful. She lived with us until she passed,  but I was away at college.  I feel like if I had seen her go through it,  I never would have started. Now I'm ashamed that I hide it from them.
I would be much healthier if I quit smoking. I would also spend a lot less money
5.  Many e-cig companies are actually owned by BIG TOBACCO companies. What do you think their motives are? To have you remain a loyal customer? To help you quit smoking? Other ideas? #ecig

Purely money making.  Some think tank probably stole the idea from a small business  startup and started pushing the advertisements and products. Of course the young are in mind because they are more attractive than cigarettes. But they certainly don't want you to stop, that cuts into their profit margins.

I think the big tobacco companies secretly feel threatened by e-cig companies, which moved them to create a link between the two, so that the big tobacco companies that have been around forever will not feel pressured by this new market. I also think big tobacco companies want to save as many customers as possible from totally cutting ties to them, which is far from helping us quit smoking. Big tobacco companies want us to keep smoking.
Big tabacco companies just want to make money and keep making money.
I think the big tobacco companies just want to continue making a profit. Cigarettes are becoming less and less "cool" with young people, so the big tobacco companies had to adjust.
I think it's partially to keep people buying products but also to appeal to the younger crowd as well.
It's all about money, in my opinion. They just want to appeal to all audiences to rake in as much as possible.

4.  For any of you who aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing and 'safer' to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious http://www.fda.gov/newsevents/publichealthfocus/ucm172906.htm
I tried ecigs but I didn't really like it. I know a lot of people around my age and younger who love it though cause of the flavors.

I find that younger people are starting to use them mostly because of their flavors, and there's still some people who are under the impression that smoking is/makes you look "cool." So you spend $30 on a vaper or ecig, you can practice smoke tricks, show off to your friends, and go home without smelling like smoke. I know for a fact there's a senior at my little sisters highschool that will buy them for younger students. (It's been reported), but I don't believe they should be used by the younger crowd because it still supports an addiction. When I tried an ecig, I missed the burn of a regular cig, so  I switched back within a month.
Yeah, I think they're more appealing to younger people. Mostly because of the flavors and mods. Not necessarily because they think they're safer, though.
I think e-cigs are much more appealing to young people because it looks "cooler" and the flavoring makes it more attractive to minors.
I think a lot of people regardless of age think the e-cigarettes are a safer alternative and that may make it more appealing to teens.

I am an avid vape user, meaning that I use e-cigarettes regularly and am an avid fan and contributor to the e-cigarette society. If I were a minor, I think an e-cig would definitely be more appealing and "safer" to try than an e-cigarette. Thinking about all of the toxins that are in a regular cigarette; an e-cigarette would almost be the utmost healthy alternative to smoking cigarettes. As a minor, I wouldn't have to mind the factors of actually smoking a real cigarette, such as physical health risks, as well as social risks. If I were a minor and an e-cigarette were available to try, I would definitely try one and I probably wouldn't still be trying to wean myself off of cigarettes to this day. The controversy between the FDA and other big wigs about e-cigarettes, I think is preposterous, I feel as though it is just a ploy between the FDA and the federal government  to maximize the tobacco taxes that already already apparent throughout the United States. In other words, the federal government wants more money and tobacco is the easiest target to regulate.
3.  How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation
Anytime they wanted a cig, call me.
Avoid smoking around them and avoid inviting them to places that allow smoking (find alternative venues to hang out).
"That's awesome dude. Text me when lever you need me."
I would avoid smoking around them and avoid situations that would cause them to want to smoke.

One of my coworkers smokes on and off so whenever I see him smoking I tell him to stop lol. If someone wanted my actual help in quitting I would try to get them to pick up another habit to replace it, like chewing gum or something. And just be there for support.

I would give them the best available resources, and I would make sure they get the support that they need to get the help they deserve. Smoking is an addiction, although not as tremulous as other addictions, and without the right support, someone will always have the need to pick up a cigarette.

Also, I would make sure he or she has the right tools necessary to quit smoking. I would be the type of friend who makes sure he or she doesn't pick up a cigarette and give him or her a nice alternative, such as an e-cigarette.
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII
2.  Educate yourself on the smoking rates and laws in your state. Search up 'smoking information' or 'smoking bans' in your state. Did any of the information surprise you? #smokingaffectsall

'The CIAA provides for penalties in case of violation of the smoking regulations.  The owner, operator or manager of the premises may be penalized for failing to post proper signage in amounts ranging from $250 to $1,000.[xv]  The owner, operator or manager of the premises may be penalized for allowing smoking where it is prohibited in amounts ranging from $250 to $1,000 and a person (patron or employ of the premises) may be penalized for smoking where it is prohibited in amounts ranging from $250 to $1,000 - See more at: http://smoking.uslegal.com/smoking-regulations-in-pennsylvania/#sthash.DYz2ZVmo.dpuf' I wasn't aware that smoking bans were so in depth.
Me either. I knew some of em for PA cause I work at a supermarket.  But not all that.
I already knew that Maine is pushing for a smoke-free state, so they have pretty tough anti-smoking laws.

"More than 500 Arkansans die each year from the effects of smoking … and the worst part is that these people are not smokers themselves. That’s why Arkansas has taken far-reaching steps to promote healthier environments and help our residents get tobacco-free.  These include environmental restrictions, tobacco taxes, and a comprehensive tobacco prevention and cessation program."

Idaho has smoking bans in most public places, but I was surprised that employers with 5 or less employees are allowed to have a smoking room in the building as long as it is kept separate from the rest of the business.

According to the Missouri Department of Health, "Smoking is the most preventable cause of disease, disability and death in Missouri." This information surprised me, given the fact that I feel as though other health risks that involve something as simple as changing your diet would be more preventable than smoking. I would think that eating a deli sandwich instead of a greasy cheeseburger would be more of a common way to prevent disease, at least, instead of smoking. Also, I know that, in almost any business establishment, other than some bars and grills in Missouri, smoking is not allowed, even e-cigarettes. This ban was placed within the span of ten years, I believe, which I think is ridiculous, especially e-cigarettes, which aren't even harmful to the environment.

data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone and welcome to the group. Tomorrow, I will be holding the first "The Doctor Is In" session from 5-6 PM (Pacific Time). You can ask me everything you want to know around smoking, quitting, and the Tobacco Status Project.

data.message: 1.  Share a success that you’ve had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped? #motivation

A few years ago, I quit for a short time by keeping a log in my pack of cigarettes. Every time I went to light up, I had to write down the time and why I was smoking (habit, stress, or reward). It helped me realize what triggered me to smoke most and then come up with plan for fixing, avoiding, or overcoming those triggers.
If it's smoking related, I switched to from cigs to vaping for about a month. If it's not cigarette related, I lost 115lbs :)
I stopped smoking for about a month. Pure willpower. Haha

Getting the job that I have now was a huge win for me. I found out from a friend that they were hiring and it's changed my life so much for the better. Making good money, having independence, constant interaction with people, etc. It just feels good to be where I'm at.

I would have to say that a success that I cherish deeply is when I finally realized i was independent and I was living this life for myself and no one else. Becoming independent worked because I told myself to never give up, and even though I hit roadblocks in the process, I still succeeded. I become fully independent at the age of 20, but I've been on my own since I was 17. My support groups have diminished and replenished, so to speak, so I guess I would have to say I helped myself get through the obstacles that were in my way.

I think my greatest success was going from high school drop out to high school graduate in just 2 years. My family motivated me to go back to school, and it worked because of my persistence and hard work.

Hello everyone! We are going to start our 90 days of posts this week so look out for that Remember: You earn $7 for each week that you comment everyday, so you could earn an extra $90 at the end of this session.Thanks for participating everyone!-Victoria from TSP
I'm excited!
Yay!

This group is for 18-25 year olds who currently smoke and are thinking of quitting. Learn more information about all the treatment options you can use, how to prepare and combat cravings and withdrawal, how to build up your support system AND get tips for successfully staying quit. Make your game plan here, then execute with confidence in the future. This group has been randomly selected to have Weekly Incentives; you can accumulate $7 at the end of every week in which you comment every day, for a gift card of up to $90 at the end of the session.

data.message: Hello
Looking forward to participating in this group!
The only time I really think about this group is when I'm sitting outside, smoking. What a shame, right? Lol but hey! I'm 10435, and I really need to quit smoking. :)
I'm vaguely trying to quit? Like I'm not really smoking unless I'm at work.
I smoke a lot lol. It'd be good to cut back I guess. It is expensive.
I'm down to one pack a week. Unless I have a drunken night with friends, but that's not often.

data.message: Do we have to wait until the actual time slot to get our questions answered?  I  seem to be working during your sessions
Hi 10435 - you can post your question at any time and I will respond tomorrow during my office hours.
Does smoking sometimes cause enlarged lympnodes  (sp) in the neck?
And thank you! I appreciate it!

Thanks for your question 10435 - you know it is very much likely that the toxins in cigarette smoke could have something to do with that. However, I am a psychologist and not a medical doctor and no doctor will be able to give you a good answer without actually seeing you. I highly recommend you see your primary health care provider and get it checked out to be certain! Let me know if there is anything else I can help you with!
